notes: Hold back planting if the month is either very cold or wet
If the month is mild, consider planting shallots (a slow growing crop)
Plant bare root fruit trees, and fruit bushes
Delay planting if weather is very cold or wet
Consider warming the beds before sowing by covering with a sheet or fleece
Choose early varieties that are suited for cold weather germination
Start germinating slow growing heat loving plants like aubergine, peppers, chillies, and tomatoes
The last opportunity to sow garlic, fruit bushes, and fruit canes
An excellent time to plant onion sets
The best time to sow heat loving plants like tomatoes, peppers, and aubergine
Sow early varieties of potatoes, peas, and carrots
Sow brassicas like cabbage, sprouts, broccoli, kale, and cauliflower under protection (cold frame, greenhouse, polytunnel)
Consider sowing fast growing crops like radish, kohlrabi, and turnip for an early summer harvest
Probably the busiest germination month of the year
Finish sowing potatoes, onions, and shallots
A great month to sow parsnip seeds, with the ground still wet to aid germination (also good for beets like chard, beetroot, spinach)
Last chance for many slow growing heat loving crops like tomatoes, chillies, aubergine
Sow squash, cucumber, and courgette plants now indoors (to be ready to go outside after the last frosts)
An excellent time to sow, or buy, herbs for the kitchen garden
Now is the best time to plant frost sensitive summer crops like sweetcorn, French beans, and runner beans
Seed can be sown directly in the soil for many types of plant
Beware of late frosts that can damage plants that are not hardy (eg squash, tomatoes, cucumbers)
A good month to sow fast growing annual herbs like basil, parsley, and coriander
Continue sowing seed directly in seed beds
Transplate seedlings to their final growing position, including frost sensitive plants like squash, courgettes, and tomatoes
Sow seeds, or transplant seedlings of climbing beans, at the base of supports
The emphasis switches to regular watering to sustain plants in dry weather, rather than fresh sowings
Avoid sowing in sustained heatwaves (seedlings can be scorched and it is difficult to keep the soil moist)
Continue sowing salad crops if the weather allows
Continue sowing fast growing successional crops like beetroot, lettuce, and radishes
Frost hardy plants like pak choi and cabbage can be sown for an autumn harvest
A good time to plant a strawberry bed, especially by taking runners off existing rows
Sow hardy varieties of spinach for a harvest the following spring
The start of the next gardening year!
Plant crops for overwintering to bring an early harvest the following year (onions, broad beans, garlic)
The start of the fruit bush planting season during their dormant period (gooseberries, currants, blackberries, summer raspberries)
If the weather is not too cold, November is an excellent month to plant bare root fruit trees and knock in stake supports (into the soft ground)
One of the best times to sow garlic
A good month to plant rhubarb crowns in a bed full of well rotted manure and compost
Continue planting fruit bushes and fruit canes
Not a bad month for a gardener to stay indoors if the weather is cold and wet!
In mild years, it may be possible to plant peas and broad beans under protection (fleece or grow tunnel)
Plant garlic
Continue planting fruit trees and fruit bushes
Autumn raspberries are now dormant, allowing the canes to be planted
